data.title: Herbie Mann
data.meta_description: With his distinctive bearded appearance, and an unorthodox playing posture which involved holding his flute pointing downwards, Herbie Mann was as immediately recognisable visually as he was aurally
data.text:
With his distinctive bearded appearance, and an unorthodox playing posture which involved holding his flute pointing downwards, Herbie Mann was as immediately recognisable visually as he was aurally. Almost single-handedly, he popularised the flute in jazz, as well as bringing a huge number of world music ideas into his work before such international mixing and matching became commonplace. His breathy, highly unusual solo style transferred easily between the many settings he chose to explore. Often derided by purist jazz critics for the unashamed populism of his concerts and recordings, Mann always maintained that he played for the “95 per cent of the public who were not jazz fans”.

His earliest recordings flirted with the boundaries between jazz and rhythm-and-blues, before he went on to help
